Your feedback helps us prioritize which bugs to investigate and address first.

body:
Hey @harsh9898 . Thanks for filing the issue. This is definitely tricky because of the transient nature of this bug. I'm guessing there's a race condition.

I unminified the JS and I may have found at least where it is happening, and it might be worthwhile to just add a guard check just in case.

I've provided here a wheel file (it is a zip file, we can rename it back to a wheel. Can you try seeing if you can reproduce the transient issue before and see if this wheel fixes it.

[streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16618027/streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.zip)

```
mv streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.zip streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl
pip install streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl
```

And see if you can reproduce it. If there's good results, I can get this change in the next release.

@kmcgrady 
Thank you so much for your reply. I will try this wheel file and let you know.

Seems like the given library wheel file of 1.37.1 fixed the issue. Thank you so much. 

But, I am seeing new issue now. I have a list of three items and using st.tabs(<list_name>) to create the tabs but on the screen it shows those three tabs and then some numbers upto 7 for a few seconds and once it stops running those numbered tabs goes away. I have noticed this every time. I have attached the screenshot for your reference. Those numbered tabs are greyed out as well. Not sure why this is happening.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6d7de74a-25b0-4711-bdab-454772b893f1)


Hope to hear from you soon.

Hey @harsh9898 Fascinating indeed. Based on the logic our frontend is iterating over the tabs, but it seems like we are detecting the list being larger (and the latter 4 is not a tab (those numbers are the index when the label is undefined).

I'll see if I can figure out what's going on.

~Hey @harsh9898 good news and bad news.~

~Good news is I think this is related to https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues/8676. They said that `st.tabs` stopped working in 1.27.0. Perhaps you can test 1.26.0 and see if it works and see if it breaks.~

~I also provided a new wheel file below. It's the same as the previous one, but it logs what it thinks those invisible tabs are. If you can share with me what the logs say, that can be very helpful (you may have to expand to show more info in the object).~

~[streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16620091/streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.zip)~

~I'm wondering if it has something to do with nested tabs causing confusion (based on your image), but I'm not 100% sure what's going on. Hoping when I see the logs I'll get a better idea.~

Ah. @harsh9898 I figured it out! Here's my reliable repro.

```python
import streamlit as st

if st.checkbox('Show do something', True):
    with st.expander("Something", expanded=True):
        st.write('Do something 1')
        st.write('Do something 2')
        st.write('Do something 3')
        st.write('Do something 4')
        st.write('Do something 5')
        st.write('Do something 6')
else:
    tab1, tab2, tab3 = st.tabs(["1", "2", "3"])
    with tab1: 
        st.info('Some info in tab1.')
    with tab2:
        st.info('Some info in tab2.')
    with tab3:
        st.info('Some info in tab3.')

import time

time.sleep(1)
```

Steps to reproduce
1. Run the app.
2. Check the box

The screen should blank out.

What happening under the hood is we are replacing one container (expander) with another container (tabs). When the switch happens, we start by keeping the children of that container. This is _old_ code, so I expect this was before we had all the containers we do now. It's also designed to not create weird experiences where elements are removed. Tabs are especially bad because it _expects_ a specific kind of child (the tab itself), come to find out it won't have that cause it inherits the children from the expander. This creates the errors you are seeing.

Good news is the change is easy. We don't preserve the children if the Block Node changes type. I should get a PR out (I need to write tests to avoid this again). You can try out the wheel file below with the fix at least and verify it works in your use case.

[streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16620489/streamlit-1.37.1-py2.py3-none-any.zip)

issue.title: Do not preserve children of a block if the block type changes

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
## Describe your changes

We have this convenience that preserves the children of a block even if a block changes. This was likely because we want to keep the same block and children and we don't want to make random elements disappear (and preserve widget state). This change keeps the existing behavior, but it _will_ reset the children if the _type_ of the block changes as well. 

## GitHub Issue Link (if applicable)
Closes #9259
Closes #8676

## Testing Plan

- Added a unit test to define the behavior accurately

---

**Contribution License Agreement**

By submitting this pull request you agree that all contributions to this project are made under the Apache 2.0 license.

body:
@kmcgrady 
You are great man! Thank you for the quick resolution. I will try the given wheel and let you know if it works or not. I have built something big using Streamlit. This is possible all because of Streamlit community and collaborators like you. 

This is the website: https://myspringy.com/

I have shared this app in the community today morning. Can you please give me feedback by using it if possible?

Thank you so much

@kmcgrady Unfortunately the issue seems still present in v1.38. I have blank pages on some browsers/tabs and not on others. Downgrading to 1.36 solved it for me. (for now!)

I do indeed make use of many tabs (5).
